001package squidpony.squidmath;
002
003
004import squidpony.StringKit;
005import squidpony.annotation.Beta;
006
007import java.io.Serializable;
008
009/**
010 * A very fast and high-quality generator, but one that is not equidistributed because it produces 64-bit longs from 63
011 * bits of state (meaning at least half of all possible long values cannot be returned by this generator). This still
012 * passes gjrand with no failures on 100 GB of test data, and PractRand with 1TB (possibly more), while sometimes being
013 * significantly faster than {@link ThrustAltRNG}. ThrustAltRNG passes PractRand at the normal limit of 32TB, but this
014 * fails it at 2TB, so this class is expected to change if an improvement is found. The inlined version of
015 * {@link #nextLong()} is the fastest generator in all of SquidLib, even counting deeply-flawed generators like
016 * {@link LapRNG}. The name comes from its origin with Thrust, but as opposed to a full-body movement for a thrust in
017 * fencing, this only "moves" some of its bits, like a jab in boxing.
018 * <br>
019 * The state is always odd here, and {@link #setState(long)} will always ensure that is maintained.
020 * <br>
021 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 11/1/2017.
022 */
023@Beta
024public final class JabRNG implements StatefulRandomness, Serializable {
025    private static final long serialVersionUID = 2L;
026    /**
027     * Can be any odd-number long value.
028     */
029    private long state;
030
031    /**
032     * Creates a new generator seeded using Math.random.
033     */
034    public JabRNG() {
035        this((long) ((Math.random() - 0.5) * 0x10000000000000L)
036                ^ (long) (((Math.random() - 0.5) * 2.0) * 0x8000000000000000L));
037    }
038
039    public JabRNG(final long seed) {
040        state = seed | 1L;
041    }
042
043    /**
044     * Get the current internal state of the StatefulRandomness as a long.
045     *
046     * @return the current internal state of this object.
047     */
048    @Override
049    public long getState() {
050        return state;
051    }
052
053    /**
054     * Set the current internal state of this StatefulRandomness with a long.
055     *
056     * @param state a 64-bit long. You may want to avoid passing 0 for compatibility, though this implementation can handle that.
057     */
058    @Override
059    public void setState(long state) {
060        this.state = state | 1L;
061    }
062
063    /**
064     * Using this method, any algorithm that might use the built-in Java Random
065     * can interface with this randomness source.
066     *
067     * @param bits the number of bits to be returned
068     * @return the integer containing the appropriate number of bits
069     */
070    @Override
071    public final int next(int bits) {
072        long z = (state += 0x3C6EF372FE94F82AL);
073        z *= (z ^ (z >>> 21));
074        return (int)(z ^ z >>> 28) >>> (32 - bits);
075    }
076
077    /**
078     * Using this method, any algorithm that needs to efficiently generate more
079     * than 32 bits of random data can interface with this randomness source.
080     * <p>
081     * Get a random long between Long.MIN_VALUE and Long.MAX_VALUE (both inclusive).
082     *
083     * @return a random long between Long.MIN_VALUE and Long.MAX_VALUE (both inclusive)
084     */
085    @Override
086    public final long nextLong() {
087        long z = (state += 0x3C6EF372FE94F82AL);
088        z *= (z ^ (z >>> 21));
089        return z ^ z >>> 28;
090    }
091
092    /**
093     * Call with {@code nextLong(z += 0x3C6EF372FE94F82AL)}. Using -= is also OK. The value for z must be odd; you
094     * can ensure this initially with {@code z |= 1} if it is set from a random source or user input. Using the given
095     * increment (or decrement) value for z will keep an odd-number value for z as an odd number; this is important to
096     * the behavior of this algorithm.
097     * @param z an odd-number long that should change with {@code z += 0x3C6EF372FE94F82AL} each time this is called
098     * @return a random long between Long.MIN_VALUE and Long.MAX_VALUE (both inclusive)
099     */
100    public static long randomize(long z) {
101        return (z *= (z ^ (z >>> 21))) ^ (z >>> 28);
102    }
103
104    /**
105     * Advances or rolls back the Jab63RNG's state without actually generating each number. Skips forward
106     * or backward a number of steps specified by advance, where a step is equal to one call to nextLong(),
107     * and returns the random number produced at that step (you can get the state with {@link #getState()}).
108     *
109     * @param advance Number of future generations to skip over; can be negative to backtrack, 0 gets the most-recently-generated number
110     * @return the random long generated after skipping forward or backwards by {@code advance} numbers
111     */
112    public final long skip(long advance) {
113        long z = (state += 0x3C6EF372FE94F82AL * advance);
114        z *= (z ^ (z >>> 21));
115        return z ^ z >>> 28;
116    }
117
118
119    /**
120     * Produces a copy of this RandomnessSource that, if next() and/or nextLong() are called on this object and the
121     * copy, both will generate the same sequence of random numbers from the point copy() was called. This just need to
122     * copy the state so it isn't shared, usually, and produce a new value with the same exact state.
123     *
124     * @return a copy of this RandomnessSource
125     */
126    @Override
127    public JabRNG copy() {
128        return new JabRNG(state);
129    }
130    @Override
131    public String toString() {
132        return "JabRNG with state 0x" + StringKit.hex(state) + 'L';
133    }
134
135    @Override
136    public boolean equals(Object o) {
137        if (this == o) return true;
138        if (o == null || getClass() != o.getClass()) return false;
139
140        JabRNG jabRNG = (JabRNG) o;
141
142        return state == jabRNG.state;
143    }
144
145    @Override
146    public int hashCode() {
147        return (int) (state >>> 1 ^ (state >>> 32));
148    }
149
150    /**
151     * Returns a random permutation of state; if state is the same on two calls to this, this will return the same
152     * number. This is expected to be called with some changing variable, e.g. {@code determine(++state)}, where
153     * the increment for state should be odd but otherwise doesn't really matter. This uses state multiplied by
154     * {@code 0x6A5D39EAE12657BAL} within this method, so using a small increment won't be much different from using a
155     * very large one, as long as it is odd. You want to use {@link #randomize(long)} instead if you can control how
156     * the state is changed and can ensure it is an odd number; randomize() uses the exact behavior of the
157     * RandomnessSource methods in class and this method doesn't, necessarily.
158     * @param state a variable that should be different every time you want a different random result;
159     *              using {@code determine(++state)} is recommended to go forwards or {@code determine(--state)} to
160     *              generate numbers in reverse order
161     * @return a pseudo-random permutation of state
162     * @see #randomize(long) randomize is meant for when you can ensure the state is odd and will be changed exactly
163     */
164    public static long determine(long state)
165    {
166        state = state * 0x3C6EF372FE94F82AL | 1L;
167        state *= (state ^ (state >>> 21));
168        return state ^ state >>> 28;
169    }
170
171    /**
172     * Given a state that should usually change each time this is called, and a bound that limits the result to some
173     * (typically fairly small) int, produces a pseudo-random int between 0 and bound (exclusive). The bound can be
174     * negative, which will cause this to produce 0 or a negative int; otherwise this produces 0 or a positive int.
175     * The state should change each time this is called, generally by incrementing by an odd number (not an even number,
176     * especially not 0). It's fine to use {@code determineBounded(++state, bound)} to get a different int each time.
177     * @param state a variable that should be different every time you want a different random result;
178     *              using {@code determineBounded(++state, bound)} is recommended to go forwards or
179     *              {@code determineBounded(--state, bound)} to generate numbers in reverse order
180     * @param bound the outer exclusive bound for the int this produces; can be negative or positive
181     * @return a pseudo-random int between 0 (inclusive) and bound (exclusive)
182     */
183    public static int determineBounded(long state, final int bound)
184    {
185        state = state * 0x3C6EF372FE94F82AL | 1L;
186        state *= (state ^ (state >>> 21));
187        return (int)((bound * ((state ^ state >>> 28) & 0x7FFFFFFFL)) >> 31);
188    }
189}
